title: What should I never say to a Scottish person? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi OA To myself: Don’t tell me England should run Scotland. Don’t call me ‘British’ or English.. ‘British’ is synonymous globally with being English so much so it’s the same thing to people outside of these isles. Don’t stereotype all of Scotland as 1960s/70s/80s Glasgow. Sure the poor places are just as rough as there & then.. but in many places you can find yourself going through endless middle class villages. Don’t expect me to care about English affairs, unless they affect Scotland. That Skripals thing is a good example.. its England arguing with Russia, not Scotland arguing with Russia. I’ve had long term Russian friends in the past.. and it seems to me that England just wants to drag everyone into their fight. Don’t tell me because you spend 5 years on holiday in Scotland studying; and your dad the multi-millionaire left Scotland when he was 7yo for England/London; you are ‘Scottish’. If you were Scottish you would 1. live here. 2. have Scottish children and raise them here. 3. Let said children endure the hardships that the rest of us did.. e.g. interact with other Scottish children (hahaha) (if you are globally Scottish, of Scottish descent, none of that was aimed at you, we get English people of Scottish descent come back up here and flash their cash they got in London, which is a huge cultural no-no and they know it and don’t care! and do it anyway!.. it’s like when Americans go to Canada, and they are *really* not supposed to talk money to Canadians.. but they do it anyway. My ex who was American did that when we were in Canada.. wow! no! The guy smiled at me and drew growlers at her) Don’t talk to me about how rich you are; or how cheap Scotland is (this is another comparison with Canada). English people do this often, brag about their money and say how cheap Scotland is, like its a compliment, when really it’s a veiled insult. I provided some ‘touchy’ answers, but it was a ‘touchy’ question to begin with, I hope the OA gets something out of my answers.

Do not ask me if i know your relatives,Scotland is not that small! Do not ask me if i am really Scottish whilst attempting to stick an orange onto my bayonet,while yer maw an paw chuckle an take photies!A £70 fine i got for kicking him a full 6 lace holes of a size 9 Highland brogue right up his sheugh!The rest of the guard had a whip round for me an we drank the wee plooks health…

Whatever should never be said to any person regardless of ethnicity, creed, age, social class or gender should never be said to a Scottish person unless in jest behind closed doors. Apart from that.., The typical for all those immediate neighbours of England:- never tell a Scottish person they are English.  I am sure other Quorans more expert than I shall soon step up the plate and answer better this question of viral import.

Never EVER call us English for a start.Never say you're quarter Scottish or something ridiculous like that.We don't pick apart people's heritage like Americans do.if you're not Scottish born and bred or at least born here then you so not claim that right.AND I'm always asked oh do you know..so and so,,they're Scottish….please..

Don’t tell us how your great great great grandfather was Scottish, refer to us as scotch or ask us if we know your friend Billy who moved to Scotland. As long as you don’t do any of those things you’ll be fine. Just treat us like normal people.
Do not assume that we are English, but also DO NOT, repeat DO NOT assume that we hate the English. Do not assume that we all support either Rangers or Celtic.

Depends how nationalistic they are but don’t tell them they aren’t Celts (even though they aren’t). Most of the Southern, Lowland Scots are as Saxon as a guy from Southampton. Edinburgh was an English town one time.

Most Scottish people, myself included, hate when people think we're English. Having said that, I worked with a Portuguese guy who 2 hated it when people thought he was Spanish, an Australian who got annoyed when people thought he was from New Zealand or South Africa and I've met Canadians on holiday who were not happy to be thought of as American. I think the same things wind us all up, basically.
